I've got lots of experience. My father died under similar circumstances 40 years ago.

Now him.

...or lack thereof. 

I know it sounds cold, but each one of them more than earned it. Over and over and over again.

I kept waiting for my brother to hit bottom. Turns out, there was no bottom for him. No matter how low it got, he just kept digging.

Not might have. Definitely.

No more waiting for the call from him, his ex-wives, ex-girlfriends, kids, the police, the RCMP, bill collectors, or total strangers telling me he'd got himself into some disaster that, somehow, unfathomably, it was not my duty to wade into and clean up.
Thank you.

I was always made out to be the monster, so I get it.

I was, however, also the one called upon to fix all the disasters everyone got themselves into...because I was the "stable" one.

My brother had a few of those, including an accident that tore the roof off his car that he'd been driving drunk. Even the cop didn't know how he survived it.

But, because he did, he took it as a sign (I assume) to keep on keepin' on.
It's a horrible feeling.

My brother was a black belt of emotional blackmail.

Which is how, when my mother died, and I was executor, I was left to clean up $50K in debt he'd got her to wrack up in uninsured loans.

He literally left his 93 year old mother destitute.

Because he never cared for anyone but himself.

"lost chances" is the perfect term. 

Mine was 9 years older as well. And, with dad gone, he was the one I looked up to.

But, like my father, women and booze and drugs took precedence over everything.

I don't grieve the loss of my family. I grieve the lost chances. The lost possibilities.

I had to step away from him 26 years ago, when he endangered the life of one of my kids.

And then put up with 25 years of my mother berating me for it.

I once asked her, "Why did you divorce dad?" She said, "because he was terrible and hurt you kids."

And I said that's why I divorced my brother.
